entry.title: New Theme For the Blog
entry.summary:
Over the weekend, I attempted to resurrect my old website/blog. The whole exercise reminded me why I stopped around the last time, namely, the sheer tedium of tweaking css/html to get things just right.

Luckily, this time around I discovered pelican, a static blog generator. It is based on python and comes with a decent number of plugins. These plugins can be used to dramatically extend or add functionality to your website. I ended up picking the liquid-plugins because it allows me to directly insert IPython notebooks, images, and more. Incidentally, the liquid_plugins was built by the famous Jake Vanderplas (of mpl3d fame). He had a nice write-up detailing how to set up liquid-plugins with pelican. Its customizable enought that I was able to add a table of contents to my notebook-based post in no time. I also ended up adding a caption option to the liquid images.

Next, I took the simply theme from Greg Reda. I really liked the responsive theme. But at the end, I ended up completely gutting the design and going with my own. So much so that I now have the moonlake theme for pelican. Its on my github repo. Feel free to use it as you see fit.

entry.title: Plot Fermi 2nd AGN Catalog Data
entry.summary:
Recreate Fermi 2LAC Plots

aimran@icecube.wisc.edu

In the previous post, I showed how to scrape the Fermi 2LAC catalog starting with a csv file and how to convert it into a fits file. Today, I will demonstrate how to actually make use of the fits file. We will be making heavy use of the fits package from astropy. It would be a good idea to review the docs page in case you get stuck with the nomenclature.

Create a fits file parser¶

We will create a small parser to quickly and efficiently read the fits file. It would be extremely tedious to have to open fits file, define tables, columns etc. Remember! If you are typing up the same thing over and over again, there is probably a better way to do things.

With that in mind, lets look at parts of FLACatalog.py (available at my github repo). We'll only focus on the important bits -- Its essentially a class that encapsulates the opening of the fits file and defines a bunch of handy getters to extract the info from relevant columns.

In []: 
class FLACatalog:
    """
    Parse the FLAC fits file and extract data from the main table.
    """
    def __init__(self, filename):
        hdulist = pyfits.open(filename)
        tbl = hdulist[1].data  # main table
        try:
            self._sn      = tbl.field("Fermi_Name")
            self._assoc   = tbl.field("CName")
            self._ra      = tbl.field("RAJ2000") * Units.degree
            self._de      = tbl.field("DEJ2000") * Units.degree
            self._l2      = tbl.field("GLON") * Units.degree
            self._b2      = tbl.field("GLAT") * Units.degree
            self._an      = tbl.field("AngSep") * Units.degree
            self._an95    = tbl.field("PosErr95deg") * Units.degree
            self._class1  = tbl.field("Class")
            self._z       = tbl.field("Redshift")
            self._sed     = tbl.field("SED_Type")
            self._bayprob = tbl.field("BayProb")
            self._rgprob  = tbl.field("LR_RGProb")
            self._xgprob  = tbl.field("LR_XGProb")
            self._nsprob  = tbl.field("LogNLogSProb")
            self._rg      = tbl.field("LR_RG")
            self._xg      = tbl.field("LR_XG")
            self._F1e3    = tbl.field("Flux1000_100000") * Units.inv_cm2s
            self._dF1e3   = tbl.field("Unc_Flux1000_100000") * Units.inv_cm2s
            self._PIdx    = tbl.field("Spectral_Index")
            self._dPIdx   = tbl.field("Unc_Spectral_Index")
            self._ts      = tbl.field("TS")
            self._radFl   = tbl.field("Radio_Flux")
            self._xrayFl  = tbl.field("Xray_Flux")
            self._usnov   = tbl.field("USNOVmag")
            self._sdss    = tbl.field("SDSSVmag")
            self._aro     = tbl.field("ARO")
            self._aox     = tbl.field("AOX")
            self._clean   = tbl.field("CLEAN")
            self._in2fgl  = tbl.field("IN_2FGL")

            self._lgnupeak = self._logNuPeak(self.aox, self.aro)

        except KeyError as detail:
            print detail
            pass

        @property
        def ra(self):
            """
            List of J2000 right ascensions for the counterpart.
            """
            return self._ra

Lets deconstruct the class FLACatalog. It accepts a filename as an argument that should correspond to the fits file we created earlier. The pyfits.open function opens the file and returns a list of header/data units (hdulist). Our main table is stored as the second element hdulist[1] [first one corresponds to the main header of the file]. Afterwards, we associate different class variables to all the table columns in the fits file using the field method. And we are almost done!

All there is left to do is to set some convenient getters to grab the columns from the catalog on demand. For brevity, I'm only showing the ra method but hopefully you get the picture.

One word of caution. There are units built into several of the fields in the catalog. Therefore, I've tried my best to take care of them in the FLACatalog. You are encouraged to check/verify for yourself.

Now we are going to move on to making use of our new found power. What better way to do it than by re-creating some of the plots that came in the original ApJ paper accompanying the catalog. I will only attempt a few of the plots. The reader is encouraged to try and fill in the rest. Happy coding!

Generate Plots¶

In [1]: 
import numpy as np
import matplotlib as mpl
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.ticker import MultipleLocator

from FLACatalog import FLACatalog, Units

We instantiate an FLACatalog object by passing in the location of the fits file we created previously.

In [2]: 
catFLA = FLACatalog('../data/fermi_2lac_v01.fits')

Figure 2¶

We will begin by re-making figure 2 in the paper above. It shows the 95% containment radius as a function of TS (or the test statistic). The plot is further divided up into different population of AGN, namely, FSRQ, BL Lacs, unknown type, and other AGN.

The first thing to do is to create a mask corresponding to the clean flag as set by the Fermi team. This is

In [3]: 
#catalog name
catName = catFLA.catalog_name

#get the full array of source types or classes
#define masks based on the names present in the catalog 
#to cut on different types of sources
srcType = catFLA.source_class
fsrqFlg = srcType == 'FSRQ'
blacFlg = srcType == 'BL Lac'
agnFlg  = srcType == 'AGU'
aguFlg  = srcType == 'AGN'
radFlg  = srcType == 'Radio Galaxy'
ssrqFlg = srcType == 'SSRQ'
stbFlg  = srcType == 'Starburst galaxy'
unidFlg = srcType == 'Unidentified'
otherFlg = (aguFlg | radFlg | ssrqFlg | stbFlg | unidFlg)

#Test statistic
ts = catFLA.ts

#95% containment radius
errRad = catFLA.error_radius

Let the plotting fiesta begin! Please note that your plot may look slightly different from mine since I use a few custom style settings.

In [4]: 
scatter_kwargs = dict(s=10, linewidths=0, edgecolors='none')

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8,6))

ax.scatter(ts[fsrqFlg], errRad[fsrqFlg], color='r', label = 'FSRQ', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(ts[blacFlg], errRad[blacFlg], color='b', label = 'BL Lacs', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(ts[agnFlg], errRad[agnFlg], color='#00FF00', label = 'Unknown Type', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(ts[otherFlg], errRad[otherFlg], color='m', label = 'Other AGN', **scatter_kwargs)

ax.legend(scatterpoints = 1)

ax.set_xscale('log')
ax.set_yscale('log')

ax.set_ylabel(u'95% Error radius [$^\circ$]')
ax.set_xlabel(u'TS')

plt.show()

Figure 6¶

Not bad! This looks very close to what you have on the paper. So, we are off to a good start. Lets plow on. We'll try figure 6 next. Its a plot of the distribution of log of synchrotron peak for 2 different species of AGN (FSRQ and BL Lac). Note that we are reusing mask from the previous along with a new clean mask as specified by the Fermi team.

In [5]: 
#clean flag
cleanFlg = catFLA.clean_flag

clean_fsrq = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, fsrqFlg)
lgnu_fsrq = catFLA.log_nu_peak[clean_fsrq]

clean_bllac = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, blacFlg)
lgnu_bllac = catFLA.log_nu_peak[clean_bllac]
In [6]: 
minorLocator = MultipleLocator(5)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8,6))
hist_kwargs = dict(bins=np.arange(12,17.5, 0.25), histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.4)
ax.hist(lgnu_fsrq, color='r', label='FSRQ', **hist_kwargs)
ax.hist(lgnu_bllac, color='b', label='BL Lacs', **hist_kwargs)
ax.set_ylim(0,80)
ax.set_xlim(12,17.5)
ax.legend(numpoints=1)
ax.set_xlabel(r'$\log(\nu_{\rm peak}^{s} [{\rm Hz}])$')
ax.set_ylabel('Number of Sources')
ax.xaxis.set_minor_locator(minorLocator)
plt.show()

Figure 7¶

Once again its pretty close! In the next couple of panels, I will blast through some more plots. It should all be fairly straight-forward from here on. The basic idea is to use numpy's powerful array masking feature to select multiple species of AGN along with variable of interest.

In [7]: 
cblac = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, blacFlg)
aoxb = catFLA.aox
arob = catFLA.aro
hspFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'HSP'
ispFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'ISP'
lspFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'LSP'

scatter_kwargs = dict(s=10, linewidths=0, edgecolors='none')

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8,6))
ax.scatter(aoxb[cblac&hspFlg], arob[cblac&hspFlg], color='b', label = 'HSP', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(aoxb[cblac&ispFlg], arob[cblac&ispFlg], color='c', label = 'ISP', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(aoxb[cblac&lspFlg], arob[cblac&lspFlg], color='g', label = 'LSP', **scatter_kwargs)

ax.legend(scatterpoints = 1)

ax.set_ylabel(r'$\alpha_{\rm RO}$')
ax.set_xlabel(r'$\alpha_{\rm OX}$')
plt.show()

Figure 8¶

In [8]: 
lg = np.log10
cfsrq = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, fsrqFlg)

cblac = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, blacFlg)
radFlx = catFLA.radio_flux
xrayFlx = catFLA.xray_flux

hspFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'HSP'
ispFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'ISP'
lspFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'LSP'

scatter_kwargs = dict(s=10, linewidths=0, edgecolors='none')

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8,6))
ax.scatter(lg(radFlx[cfsrq]), lg(xrayFlx[cfsrq]), color='r', label = 'FSRQ', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(lg(radFlx[cblac&hspFlg]), lg(xrayFlx[cblac&hspFlg]), color='b', label = 'HSP', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(lg(radFlx[cblac&ispFlg]), lg(xrayFlx[cblac&ispFlg]), color='c', label = 'ISP', **scatter_kwargs)
ax.scatter(lg(radFlx[cblac&lspFlg]), lg(xrayFlx[cblac&lspFlg]), color='g', label = 'LSP', **scatter_kwargs)

ax.legend(scatterpoints = 1)

ax.set_ylabel(r'$\log\ ({\rm X-ray\ flux\ [erg\ cm^{-2}\ sec^{-1}]})$')
ax.set_xlabel(r'$\log\ ({\rm S_{1.4} [mJy]})$')
plt.show()

Figure 10¶

This plot shows a normalized distribution of number of sources as a function of galactic latitude. Note I use the weights argument to specify the normalization factor.

In [9]: 
cfsrq = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, fsrqFlg)
cblac = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, blacFlg)
cunkwn = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1,agnFlg)

#normalization factors
w1 = np.ones_like( catFLA.b2[cfsrq] )/catFLA.b2[cfsrq].size
w2 = np.ones_like(catFLA.b2[cblac]) / catFLA.b2[cblac].size
w3 = np.ones_like(catFLA.b2[cunkwn]) / catFLA.b2[cunkwn].size

hist_kwargs = dict(bins=np.arange(-1,1.1, 0.1), histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.4)
fig, ax = plt.subplots(3, figsize=(8,8))


ax[0].hist(np.sin(catFLA.b2[cfsrq]), color='r', label='FSRQ', weights=w1,**hist_kwargs)
ax[0].legend(loc=9)
ax[1].hist(np.sin(catFLA.b2[cblac]), color='b', label='BL Lacs', weights=w2, **hist_kwargs)
ax[1].legend(loc=9)
ax[2].hist(np.sin(catFLA.b2[cunkwn]), color='g', label='Unknown', weights=w3, **hist_kwargs)
ax[2].legend(loc=9)

ax[1].set_ylabel(r'Normalized # of sources')
ax[2].set_xlabel(r'$\sin({\rm b})$')

for i in [0,1,2]:
    ax[i].set_ylim(0,0.13)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

Figure 12¶

Okay, this is the last plot, I promise! I'll leave a few for you to figure out. This plot shows the number distribution of AGN as a function of redshift.

In [10]: 
cfsrq = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, fsrqFlg)
cblac = np.logical_and(cleanFlg==1, blacFlg)

hspFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'HSP'
ispFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'ISP'
lspFlg = catFLA.sed_type == 'LSP'
valid = catFLA.redshift > 0.

rs = catFLA.redshift

w1 = np.ones_like( rs[cfsrq] )/rs[cfsrq].size
w2 = np.ones_like(rs[cblac&valid]) / rs[cblac&valid].size
w3 = np.ones_like(rs[cblac&valid]) / rs[cblac].size
w3h = np.ones_like(rs[cblac&hspFlg&valid]) / rs[cblac&hspFlg&valid].size
w3i = np.ones_like(rs[cblac&ispFlg&valid]) / rs[cblac&ispFlg&valid].size
w3l = np.ones_like(rs[cblac&lspFlg&valid]) / rs[cblac&lspFlg&valid].size


hist_kwargs = dict(bins=np.arange(0,3.6, 0.1), histtype='step', alpha=1.)
fig, ax = plt.subplots(3, figsize=(8,8))

ax[0].hist(rs[cfsrq], color='r', label='FSRQ', weights=w1,**hist_kwargs)
ax[0].legend(loc=1)

ax[1].hist(rs[cblac&valid], color='b', weights=w2, label='BL Lacs',  **hist_kwargs)
ax[1].legend(loc=1)

ax[2].hist(rs[cblac&hspFlg&valid], color='b', weights=w3h, label='HSP', **hist_kwargs)
ax[2].hist(rs[cblac&ispFlg&valid], color='c', weights=w3i, label='ISP', **hist_kwargs)
ax[2].hist(rs[cblac&lspFlg&valid], color='g', weights=w3l, label='LSP', **hist_kwargs)
ax[2].legend(loc=1)

ax[1].set_ylabel(r'Normalized # of sources')
ax[2].set_xlabel(r'Redshift')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

Whew! That was a lot of fun. I hope this notebook shows you how easy it is to grab data from the web and start getting plotting. However, the use of IPython notebook kicks it up a notch. Code, plot and documentation-- all in one page.

entry.title: Convert 2LAC catalog to a fits file
entry.summary:
Generating fits version of 2LAC Catalog

Asif Imran (aimran@icecube.wisc.edu)

The Fermi Large Area Telescope recently released a catalog of active galacic nuclei (AGN) based on last 2 years of scientific operation. Obviously, for anyone studying the extra-galactic sky in gamma rays, the 2nd year AGN catalog (2LAC) is a treasure field. Fermi released a number of their previous catalogs in the convenient FITS format. However, the 2LAC somehow did not make the list.

Fortunately for us, the ASI Science Data Center (ASDC), a facility of the Italian Space agency (ASI) maintains a very helpful online version of several Fermi catalogs, incuding 2LAC. Moreover, they allow you to download the entire catalog in csv format! I figured its worth an afternoon's work to convert the csv file into one in FITS format.

I went ahead and selected all fields and all entries using the web-form and downloaded a csv file. As it turns out, the csv database is a tad dirty. Therefore, a good part of my little afternoon hack was spent trying to clean up the mess. I'm documenting my work in hopes that it may be useful for some. In a latter notebook, I will show how to conveniently parse the resulting FITS file.

In [1]: 
from astropy.io import fits as pyfits
import numpy as np
from StringIO import StringIO
from datetime import datetime

Cleaning up the Column Names and Data Types¶

It turns out that some of the column names had traling empty spaces in them. In addition, there are quite a few null values. As a result, numpy fails to reliably determine the data types for several columns. I went through the csv header and decided to hard-wire all the column names along with the data types. I will come back later to fix the null entries.

In [2]: 
conv_type = [('Fermi_Name', '|S17'), ('CName', '|S22'), 
             ('RAJ2000', 'float32'), ('DEJ2000', 'float32'), 
            ('GLON', 'float32'), ('GLAT', 'float32'), 
            ('AngSep', 'float32'), ('PosErr95deg', 'float32'), 
            ('Class', '|S16'), ('Redshift', 'float32'),
            ('SED_Type', '|S3'), ('BayProb', 'float32'), 
            ('LR_RGProb', 'float32'),('LR_XGProb', 'float32'), 
            ('LogNLogSProb', 'float32'), 
            ('LR_RG', 'float32'), ('LR_XG', 'float32'), 
            ('Flux1000_100000', 'float32'), 
            ('Unc_Flux1000_100000', 'float32'),
            ('Spectral_Index', 'float32'),
            ('Unc_Spectral_Index', 'float32'), 
            ('TS', 'float32'), ('Radio_Flux', 'float32'), 
            ('Xray_Flux', 'float32'), ('USNOVmag', 'float32'), 
            ('SDSSVmag', 'float32'), ('ARO', 'float32'), 
            ('AOX', 'float32'), ('CLEAN', '<i4'), 
            ('IN_2FGL', '<i4')]

Here are a some handy converters that we can feed into numpy's fabulous genfromtxt routine. It has tons of knobs (compared to, say, the simple loadtxt) that you can use to really fine tune your data munging.

In [3]: 
# Fairly obvious what these does... turns '-' 
# into reasonable values
def convertToFloat(s):
    if s == '-':
        return np.inf   
    else:
        return float(s)

def fixClass(s):
    if s == '-':
        return 'None'
    else:
        return s

# I find it easier to deal with 1/0 instead of YES/NO
def convertYesNoToBool(s):
    if s == 'YES':
        return 1
    elif s== 'NO':
        return 0
    else:
        if s != '1': print 'Can not convert to bool', s
        return 99

Open the csv file. I saved it as 'fermi2LAC_raw_data.csv'. I then use genfromtxt to convert it to a numpy array. Note that the use of dtype now allows me to refer to the columns by names (as specified by the keys in conv_type). Also, I really like the use of converters to deal with null entries at the time of reading the file (a great example of functional programming, IMO). Finally, we have a structured array, conveniently named data that corresponds to all the entries read from the csv files.

In [4]: 
fil = open('../data/fermi2LAC_raw_data.csv')

my_converters = {'Class':fixClass, 
                 'TS':convertToFloat, 
                 'AOX': convertToFloat, 
                 'ARO': convertToFloat,
                 'Radio_Flux': convertToFloat,
                 'Xray_Flux': convertToFloat,
                 'USNOVmag': convertToFloat,
                 'SDSSVmag': convertToFloat, 
                 'CLEAN':convertYesNoToBool, 
                 'IN_2FGL':convertYesNoToBool}
data = np.genfromtxt(fil, comments='#',
                     delimiter=',', 
                     autostrip=True, 
                     names=True, dtype=conv_type, 
                     converters= my_converters
                     )

A quick sanity check (not meant to be complete) to see if we have any unreasonable data (e.g., stray characters, quotes etc.) still lurking in the data array.

In [5]: 
def checkValid(x, show=False):
    if data.dtype[x] != np.dtype('float32'): return 'N/A'
    a = np.isnan(data[x])
    if np.sum(a) > 0 :return False
    else: return True
    
for name in data.dtype.names:
    c = checkValid(name)
    if c is False:
        print name,"\t\t", checkValid(name)

Creating FITS File¶

At this point, we are in a reasonable shape to try and attempt to create the FITS file. FITS is an open standard, digital file format used throughout the astronomy community. It's heavily used by astronomers for the purposes of storing large images/data sets, transferring data over the wire and performing routine analysis. I will avoid delving into the details of actual FITS standards but the reader may find it useful to carefully go over them.

Fortunately for us pythonistas', there is a great package called pyfits that makes generating FITS files and dealing with them almost a breeze. Although pyfits is marked to be deprecated in the near future, it has found a new home with the great astropy community. The goal is to eventually provide a drop-in replacement for the originalpyfits within astropy.

In order to build the FITS table from our data, we need to provide the unit, a short description and a data type for each of the field to be stored in FITS format. One can concievably skip this step all together but then the resulting FITS file may become incomprehensible as time passes ("Was RA in degrees or radians??"). So, I decided to fill in the details to the best of my abilities. There is of course a convenient table of description for each of the fields in the original paper accompanying the 2LAC release-- I cut and pasted as appropriate.

In [6]: 
#Dictionary of units for each field
unitmap = dict((('Fermi_Name', None), ('CName', None), 
                ('RAJ2000', 'deg'), ('DEJ2000', 'deg'), 
                ('GLON', 'deg'), ('GLAT', 'deg'), 
                ('AngSep', 'deg'),('PosErr95deg', 'deg'), 
                ('Class', None), ('Redshift', None), 
                ('SED_Type', None), ('BayProb', None), 
                ('LR_RGProb', None), ('LR_XGProb', None), 
                ('LogNLogSProb', None), ('LR_RG', None),
                ('LR_XG', None), 
                ('Flux1000_100000', 'photon/cm2/s'), 
                ('Unc_Flux1000_100000', 'photon/cm2/s'),
                ('Spectral_Index', None), 
                ('Unc_Spectral_Index', None), 
                ('TS', None), ('Radio_Flux', 'mJy'),
                ('Xray_Flux', 'erg/cm2/s'), ('USNOVmag', None), 
                ('SDSSVmag', None), ('ARO', None), 
                ('AOX', None), 
                ('CLEAN',  None), ('IN_2FGL', None)))

#Dictionary of descriptions for each field
descmap = dict((('Fermi_Name', 'Name of the 2FGL source'), 
                ('CName', 'Name of the counterpart'), 
                ('RAJ2000', 'Right Ascension (J2000) of the counterpart'),
                ('DEJ2000', 'Declination (J2000) of the counterpart'),
                ('GLON', 'Galactic Longitude'), ('GLAT', 'Galactic Latitude'), 
                ('AngSep', 'Ang. between 2FGL and its counterpart'),
                ('PosErr95deg', '95% error radius'), ('Class', 'Optical class'), 
                ('Redshift', 'Redshift'), 
                ('SED_Type', 'SED class based on the synch. peak freq.'), 
                ('BayProb', 'Bayesian probability'), 
                ('LR_RGProb', 'LH prob. for Radio-gamma assoc.'), 
                ('LR_XGProb', 'LH prob. for X-gamma association'), 
                ('LogNLogSProb', 'logN-logS probability'), 
                ('LR_RG', 'LH Ratio reliability for Radio-gamma assoc'),
                ('LR_XG', 'LH Ratio reliability for X-gamma assoc.'), 
                ('Flux1000_100000', 'Photon flux for 1 GeV-100 GeV'), 
                ('Unc_Flux1000_100000', 'Error in photon flux for 1 GeV-100 GeV'),
                ('Spectral_Index', 'Spectral Index'), 
                ('Unc_Spectral_Index', 'Error on Spectral Index'), 
                ('TS', 'Test Statistics: significance'), 
                ('Radio_Flux', 'Radio flux'), ('Xray_Flux', 'X ray band flux'), 
                ('USNOVmag', 'V Magnitude from USNO B1'), 
                ('SDSSVmag', 'V Magnitude from SDSS'), 
                ('ARO', 'Spectral index between radio and Opt. band'), 
                ('AOX', 'Spectral index between opt. and X band'), 
                ('CLEAN', 'Flag for a source in the Clean sample'), 
                ('IN_2FGL', 'Flag for a source in the 2FGL List')))

#Dictionary of data types for each field
dispmap = dict((('Fermi_Name', 'A17'), ('CName', 'A22'), 
                ('RAJ2000', 'F8.4'), ('DEJ2000', 'F8.4'), 
                ('GLON', 'F8.4'), ('GLAT', 'F8.4'),
                ('AngSep', 'F8.4'), ('PosErr95deg', 'F8.4'), 
                ('Class', 'A16'), ('Redshift', 'F8.4'), 
                ('SED_Type', 'A3'), ('BayProb', 'F8.3'), 
                ('LR_RGProb', 'F8.3'), ('LR_XGProb', 'F8.3'), 
                ('LogNLogSProb', 'F8.3'), ('LR_RG', 'F8.3'), 
                ('LR_XG', 'F8.3'),('Flux1000_100000', 'E10.4'), 
                ('Unc_Flux1000_100000', 'E10.4'), 
                ('Spectral_Index', 'F8.4'), 
                ('Unc_Spectral_Index', 'F8.4'),
                ('TS', 'F8.3'), ('Radio_Flux', 'F10.4'),
                ('Xray_Flux', 'E10.4'), ('USNOVmag', 'F8.3'),
                ('SDSSVmag', 'F8.3'), ('ARO', 'F8.3'), 
                ('AOX', 'F8.3'), ('CLEAN', None), 
                ('IN_2FGL', None)))


fitFormatType = {}
#Here is a translation of numpy dtype into FITS dtype
locmap = {'S':'A','f':'E','i':'I'} 
for d in data.dtype.names:
    f = data[d].dtype.str
    f = f[1:] #discard the dtype qualifier
    fitType = locmap[f[0]]
    fitLen = f[1:]
    fitFormat = fitType+fitLen
    fitFormatType[d] = fitFormat

Create an array of pyfits.columns that will shortly be written into the FITS file

In [7]: 
columns = []
#create a pyfit.column for each of the column in our data array
for d in data.dtype.names:
    columns.append(pyfits.Column(name=d, 
                                 format=fitFormatType[d], 
                                 unit=unitmap[d],
                                 disp = dispmap[d], 
                                 array=data[d]))
print columns

[name = 'Fermi_Name'; format = 'A17'; disp = 'A17', name = 'CName'; format = 'A22'; disp = 'A22', name = 'RAJ2000'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'deg'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'DEJ2000'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'deg'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'GLON'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'deg'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'GLAT'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'deg'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'AngSep'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'deg'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'PosErr95deg'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'deg'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'Class'; format = 'A16'; disp = 'A16', name = 'Redshift'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'SED_Type'; format = 'A3'; disp = 'A3', name = 'BayProb'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'LR_RGProb'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'LR_XGProb'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'LogNLogSProb'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'LR_RG'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'LR_XG'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'Flux1000_100000'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'photon/cm2/s'; disp = 'E10.4', name = 'Unc_Flux1000_100000'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'photon/cm2/s'; disp = 'E10.4', name = 'Spectral_Index'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'Unc_Spectral_Index'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.4', name = 'TS'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'Radio_Flux'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'mJy'; disp = 'F10.4', name = 'Xray_Flux'; format = 'E4'; unit = 'erg/cm2/s'; disp = 'E10.4', name = 'USNOVmag'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'SDSSVmag'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'ARO'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'AOX'; format = 'E4'; disp = 'F8.3', name = 'CLEAN'; format = 'I4', name = 'IN_2FGL'; format = 'I4']

At long last, we are ready to write the file. The actual python command for it is very terse indeed.

In [9]: 
# Create primary header/data unit (mandatory for every file)
hdu = pyfits.PrimaryHDU()

# Add helpful/descriptive fields to the header, includig a checksum 
hdu.header.set('FILENAME','fermi_2lac_v01.fits',after='EXTEND')
hdu.header.set('VERSION','v01', after='FILENAME')
hdu.add_checksum(override_datasum=False)

# Define columns for the FITS table
cols = pyfits.ColDefs(columns)

# Define a FITS data table containing all your column
tbhdu = pyfits.new_table(cols)

# Append description to each of the field names
for k in tbhdu.header.cards:
    if k.value in descmap.keys():
        tbhdu.header.comments[k.keyword] = descmap[k.value]
        
# More comments-- who created it etc.
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT','',after='TFIELDS')
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT','*** End of mandatory fields ***',
                 after=('COMMENT',0))
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT','',after=('COMMENT',1))
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT','',after=('COMMENT',2))
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT',
                 'Author: Asif Imran (aimran_at_icecube_dot_wisc_dot_edu)',
                 after=('COMMENT',3))
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT',
                 'Created on %s'%datetime.today().strftime("%m-%d-%Y %H:%M"),
                 after=('COMMENT',4))
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT','*** Columns names ***',after=('COMMENT',5))
tbhdu.header.set('COMMENT','',after=('COMMENT',6))

# Finally, create HDUList object and dump it to the file
# Note: clobber means that the script will freely overwrite any file
#       with same name. You've been warned!!!
hdulist = pyfits.HDUList([hdu, tbhdu])
hdulist.writeto('fermi_2lac_v01.fits', clobber=True)

Yay! At this point, we have a brand-new FITS file that will hopefully be useful to our analysis. Lets take it out for a spin, shall we? Peek into the file you just created using pyfits.getheader function. This pretty-prints the header we wrote not too long ago. Let check and make sure that everything looks okay.

In [10]: 
pyfits.getheader('fermi_2lac_v01.fits',1)
Out[10]:

Analyzing the FITS file¶

In the next day or two, I hope to post more information on how to actually use the FITS file in your analysis. Stay tuned!
